modules.description: This module implements numerical solvers for ordinary differential equations (ODEs) using array-based state representations. It provides specific integration methods including Euler, midpoint, RK4, RK23, and RK45, with support for both fixed and adaptive step sizes. These operations are used to simulate dynamic systems in fields like physics, engineering, and computational biology.

This module implements numerical integration routines for solving ordinary differential equations (ODEs) with support for fixed-step, symplectic, and adaptive-step methods. It operates on arrays (`M.arr`) and scalar elements (`M.elt`), handling state representations in row, column, or arbitrary array forms. Concrete use cases include simulating dynamical systems, solving initial value problems, and performing physics-based computations requiring precise time-stepping.

This module implements symplectic integrators for Hamiltonian systems, where the state consists of position and momentum variables represented as pairs of `M.arr` arrays. It provides specific integration methods—symplectic Euler, leapfrog, pseudoleapfrog, Ruth 3rd-order, and Ruth 4th-order—for evolving these systems over time with energy-preserving properties. These methods are suitable for simulating physical systems such as planetary motion or molecular dynamics, where conservation of energy and phase space volume is critical.

This module implements numerical solvers for ordinary differential equations using array-based state representations. It provides integration methods such as Euler, midpoint, RK4, RK23, and RK45, supporting both fixed and adaptive step sizes. These functions are used to simulate dynamic systems in physics, engineering, and computational biology.

This module implements symplectic integrators for Hamiltonian systems using pairs of `M.arr` arrays to represent position and momentum. It provides specific methods like symplectic Euler, leapfrog, and Ruth's 3rd- and 4th-order schemes to evolve such systems while preserving energy and phase space structure. These integrators are used in simulations of physical systems such as celestial mechanics and molecular dynamics where conservation properties are essential.

This module provides numerical integration for systems of ordinary differential equations (ODEs) using customizable solvers. It operates on state vectors and time specifications, evolving solutions through fixed or adaptive step methods. Concrete use cases include simulating physical systems, solving initial value problems, and modeling dynamic processes in engineering and science.

This module defines types for specifying integration intervals and parameters used by ODE solvers. It supports three configurations: fixed duration with initial time and step, explicit start and end times with step, and an array-based time sequence. These types directly configure solvers to handle numerical integration tasks over specified time ranges.

This module provides numerical integration routines for solving ordinary differential equations (ODEs), supporting fixed-step, symplectic, and adaptive-step methods. It operates on arrays (`M.arr`) and scalar elements (`M.elt`), accommodating state representations in various array layouts. It is used for simulating dynamical systems, solving initial value problems, and performing physics-based computations requiring precise time-stepping.

This module provides numerical integration routines for solving ordinary differential equations (ODEs), supporting fixed-step, adaptive-step, and symplectic methods. It operates on array-based state representations (`M.arr`) and scalar elements (`M.elt`), with specific integrators for Hamiltonian systems using position-momentum pairs. It is used for simulating dynamical systems in physics, engineering, and computational biology, including celestial mechanics, molecular dynamics, and initial value problems requiring precise time-stepping.
